I normally lurk and do not post or comment, but I came to say that this sub has done amazing wonders for my mental health. My healing process has been so much better knowing I'm not alone and having a safe place to vent anger, laugh about ridiculous TBM shit, and find stories of people living their best lives. I'm still struggling, but even reading these posts has lended me a hand. :)

WRITING.TITLE: The Cognitive Dissonance is FIERCE
WRITING.TEXT: My TBM mom: you know, Joseph Smith was against slavery. Me (with a Bachelor's degree in US history): ...but mom, he pretty much owned slaves. Mom: Yes, but he was KIND to them. He owned slaves so that he could show them a better life. Me: so, why didn't he free them or pay them? Mom: He couldn't just do that! You don't know anything about church history. This is also the mom that claims "marrying older men at 14 was normal and common back then" (it most certainly wasn't, there was actually a trend of women marrying younger men in rural areas). I spent a lot of money and a lot of time getting my degrees. I'm 27 and going to be starting my PhD program this year. It is so frustrating that my mom (who has a degree in nursing and doesn't let anyone question her on those topics) doesn't seem to believe that I know what I'm talking about, and treats me as if I lost ALL knowledge as soon as I left the church. History has shown us that our heroes are extremely flawed. Teddy Roosevelt (one of my personal heroes) was racist and xenophobic, and I don't excuse his behavior, but I still think he was a great man otherwise and there are a lot of great qualities and ideas he had. We can have flawed heroes, appreciate what they do right, and acknowledge what they do wrong, and LEARN FROM THEM. If Mormons still love whatever good qualities they can find about JS, so be it, but recognizing his flaws AS FLAWS is the only way they will move forward. It would STRENGTHEN their cause to recognize it, and yet...they don't. Thanks for coming to my TED talk. End rant. Edited: clarity

Sorry for not having more context/clarification. While there is no formal evidence of him owning slaves, he supported slave labor on the Nauvoo Temple and encouraged slave labor from slave owners of his congregation. I equate this to owning slaves, since he pretty much owned the congregation. Either way, he had the power to free them (by ordering it in the church) and he didn't. I can't find sources right now because I'm traveling, but here is a brief wiki: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mormonism_and_slavery
I can find sources for you about the temple construction a little later :)
Man, those vitamin pills couldn't even prepare me for THIS!
Yes! Exactly. Like I could say that RMN set fire to a live human child and without missing a beat it would be "well he did it to save them."

Public shaming to keep people docile is the only way they keep control of their cult members. It's so disgusting and causes so many unrealistic self expectations and ideas about worthiness. It's no wonder there is such a high rate of suicide among teens.
Completed! Would love to see your results when the data is gathered.
What's interesting to me is that Mormons have the highest "some college" rates; likely all the kids in college getting married before they graduate
Trust issues. I don't listen to people. I am a perfectionist. I can be nit-picky
It is a big deal, especially if it bothers you! It's okay to be upset about this and you should bring it up. Your feelings are totally valid here, friend.

I have been there, friend. It is such a hard place to be forced into. But all I can say is that it gets better. Lean on non-church friends who love you for who you are. Look into self compassion YouTube videos for coping meditation. Write. Remember that your anger is justified. You're almost through. If you ever need any support or advice from someone who has been there, feel free to dm me. I will listen without judgment. It DOES get better though. You might not believe it right now, but repeat it in your head. It gets better.

WRITING.TITLE: This Group Gives Me Hope.
WRITING.TEXT: I just want to pat everyone here on the virtual back. Holy shit we have been through a lot, and it's so easy to be angry, but I've seen countless of examples of genuine compassion and friendship here that I never saw in the cult. You all give me hope with your willingness to pick others up, help out missionaries, give advice and comfort to those dealing with crashing shelves, and provide a safe harbor for folks (ESPECIALLY young folks) who face the rejection of their families. I was a teenager struggling in silence and living a double life for years in the church. It exacerbated my ptsd, depression, and anxiety to the point that I have more health problems than I would like to have. And I know that if I had a group like this, I would have felt so much more supported than I was on my journey. I don't regret it, but I wouldn't go back either. You people make a difference and I just want to let you know the impact I see here. Thank y'all for being alive.
Added! Nomechompsky from CA
Added! Nomechompsky

It's super great that you are looking out for your dad though. I agree with the comment above, validating him as a grown human who is allowed to get drunk and return safely to their own home is probably best. If you show your support and nonjudgment for him, he will definitely feel much safer talking to you about your shelf breaking when the time is right.

I'm getting closer to the end of my detox. I have an appetite. I played with my dog outside. I want to live and I know that using and drinking will kill me. I am so grateful for my sobriety today. Edit because I forgot to add that IWNDWYT!

Hey friend, I just spent the weekend in the hospital because of an attempt. I'm telling you right now it's not worth it. Force yourself to do anything else, just for the next 48 hours. Call someone until they answer the phone and tell them you're not safe to be alone. And respond somewhere here so that we know you don't need a welfare check. Losing a companion is one of the most painful experiences and that grief is incredibly painful. But you need to stay alive, please.
He is an Australian Shepherd and he is one of my top 5 reasons for staying sober!

Iwndwyt! Here are some things you can do: -Draw a silly picture of a dog riding a giraffe into the sunset. -Text or call your dearest family member or friend just to tell them that you are grateful for them. -watch a stupid show on tv. -take a bath or shower. -listen to a podcast! If you are into horror podcasts, I recommend creepy, SCP, and letsnotmeet. -read a book. There are a bunch of cheap/free kindle books. One I recommend is heroes of the frontier by dave eggers. Very good.

WRITING.TITLE: 7th day sober and I read something really helpful today
WRITING.TEXT: I am reading a memoir of one of my favorite celebrities, and she says, "everything you prioritize above your sobriety is everything you will lose to your addiction." This really hit home. I can't focus on my schooling, or work, or finances, or family, or friends until I focus on my sobriety. I need to put my sobriety first, or my addiction will destroy all of those parts of my life. Every other time I've tried to stop drinking and using, I've always wanted to do it by focusing on these other things instead of focusing on my addiction and quieting its voice, and those times have all failed. Now it's time that I focus on my sobriety first, and allow all those other things to fall into place. Just some food for thought and a sobriety check in because my therapist advised me to share when I found good bits of reading. IWNDWYT!
Laura Clery! It's called Idiot. Very funny and a great read.
"Idiot" by Laura Clery. Definitely recommend!
IWNDWYT!
Congrats! IWNDWYT!
Me too!
IWNDWYT! Having a rough day and really feeling the voice of my addiction!

I had a busy/good day, really bonded with my family and did a great job at work. But I forgot to do my sobriety journaling. So now I feel bad/like I'm failing, because I've decided that journaling is a core part of my sobriety. Time to meditate on some self-compassion and prepare to try again tomorrow. I didn't drink or want to drink, and this check-in IS a form of working the program for me, so I'm not too down. Anyway, IWNDWYT!
